title: China donates anti-epidemic materials and medical equipment to Malawi in June 2021
description: On June 2, 2021, the Chinese government donated the fourth batch of anti-epidemic materials and medical equipment to Malawi. The donation was performed during a handover ceremony at the Malaysian Ministry of Health. The USD value of the donation is unknown.   The donation is part of the China-Africa Counterpart Hospital Cooperation Mechanism. Liu Hongyang, the Chinese ambassador to Malawi, and Kumbize Chiponda, the Minister of Health of Malawi, attended the ceremony. Li Xiaogang, the captain of the Chinese medical team to Malawi, and Mwasabbo, the permanent secretary of the Ministry of Health of Malawi, also attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates anti-epidemic materials and medical equipment to Malawi in June 2021

# Description
On June 2, 2021, the Chinese government donated the fourth batch of anti-epidemic materials and medical equipment to Malawi. The donation was performed during a handover ceremony at the Malaysian Ministry of Health. The USD value of the donation is unknown.   The donation is part of the China-Africa Counterpart Hospital Cooperation Mechanism. Liu Hongyang, the Chinese ambassador to Malawi, and Kumbize Chiponda, the Minister of Health of Malawi, attended the ceremony. Li Xiaogang, the captain of the Chinese medical team to Malawi, and Mwasabbo, the permanent secretary of the Ministry of Health of Malawi, also attended the ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of medical equipment and materials, unrelated to energy or environmental impact
evidence: Donation of anti-epidemic materials and medical equipment, healthcare focus

title: Chinese Embassy in Malawi donates epidemic prevention materials to the UNHCR Representative Office in Malawi to support Malawi Refugees in June 2021
description: On June 3, 2021, the Embassy in Malawi held a handover ceremony for the donation of epidemic prevention materials to the UNHCR Representative Office in Malawi. The donation will be used for the protection of Malawi refugees. The USD value of the donation is unknown.   The ceremony was attended by Liu Hongyang, Ambassador to Malawi, and Modeste Kuameh, the representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Malawi.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Description
On June 3, 2021, the Embassy in Malawi held a handover ceremony for the donation of epidemic prevention materials to the UNHCR Representative Office in Malawi. The donation will be used for the protection of Malawi refugees. The USD value of the donation is unknown.   The ceremony was attended by Liu Hongyang, Ambassador to Malawi, and Modeste Kuameh, the representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Malawi.
justification: Project focuses on humanitarian aid and epidemic prevention, with no direct energy or environmental implications
evidence: Donation of epidemic prevention materials, support for refugee protection, health sector focus

title: China donates K40 million in medical supplies to the Shaping Our Future Foundation in December 2021 (Linked to Project ID#97702)
description: On December 3, 2021, the Chinese Government donated K40 million in medical supplies to the First Lady's Shaping Our Future Foundation in Malawi. The donation occurred at a handover ceremony which was held at the Presidential Palace of Malawi. Ambassador Liu Hongyang, President Ma's wife Monica Chakwila, and Vice Minister of Health Chrissy Kanyasho attended the ceremony and delivered speeches.  The donation will be used to protect the health of Malawian citizens and will be distributed to health facilities across the country. During the ceremony, the Chinese Government also donated K24 million (Project ID#97702) to the foundation to support girls' education.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

Ambassador Liu Hongyang, President Ma's wife Monica Chakwila, and Vice Minister of Health Chrissy Kanyasho attended the ceremony and delivered speeches.  The donation will be used to protect the health of Malawian citizens and will be distributed to health facilities across the country. During the ceremony, the Chinese Government also donated K24 million (Project ID#97702) to the foundation to support girls' education.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare and medical supplies, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medical supplies to protect health of Malawian citizens, distribution to health facilities

title: China provides K200 million in agricultural assistance to Malawi in November 2021
description: On November 26, 2021, the Chinese government provided K200 million in agriculture assistance to Malawi. The donation took place at a handover ceremony in the Calunbo area of Lilongwe. The donation will be used to support Malawi in its construction of a rural area, green greenhouses, and the cultivation of vegetables. The donation is also an effort to relieve the Malawian people of poverty.   Liu Hongyang, Ambassador to Malawi, Malaysian Minister of Agriculture, Robin Lowe, and former Malaysian President Joyce Banda attended the ceremony and delivered speeches respectively. The China Agricultural Expert Group, President Ma's Village Transformation Advisor, Malaysian Parliamentarians, local government officials, traditional leaders, and villagers' representatives participated in the event.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title

# Description
On November 26, 2021, the Chinese government provided K200 million in agriculture assistance to Malawi. The donation took place at a handover ceremony in the Calunbo area of Lilongwe. The donation will be used to support Malawi in its construction of a rural area, green greenhouses, and the cultivation of vegetables. The donation is also an effort to relieve the Malawian people of poverty.   Liu Hongyang, Ambassador to Malawi, Malaysian Minister of Agriculture, Robin Lowe, and former Malaysian President Joyce Banda attended the ceremony and delivered speeches respectively. The China Agricultural Expert Group, President Ma's Village Transformation Advisor, Malaysian Parliamentarians, local government officials, traditional leaders, and villagers' representatives participated in the event.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural assistance and poverty relief without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Agriculture assistance, rural area construction, greenhouses, vegetable cultivation, poverty relief focus

title: China donates newly constructed K188 million Nsipe Police Post to Malawi in May 2021
description: On May 18, 2021, the Chinese government donated a newly constructed Nsipe Police Post to the Government of Malawi. The Nsipe Police Post, located in the Ntcheu District, will be used to assist Malawi in its reduction of road accidents and crime. It will serve a population of about 80 thousand Malawian people from Traditional Authorities Kwataine, Makwangwala, and Champiti. The Nsipe Police Post is worth K188 million.   The donation occurred at a handover ceremony, where Chinese Ambassador to Malawi Liu Hongyang and Malawi Vice President Saulos Chilima were in attendance. In addition to the Nsipe Police Post, the Chinese government also donated furniture, five motorbikes, and a refrigerator to assist the new facility.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates newly constructed K188 million Nsipe Police Post to Malawi in May 2021

# Description
On May 18, 2021, the Chinese government donated a newly constructed Nsipe Police Post to the Government of Malawi. The Nsipe Police Post, located in the Ntcheu District, will be used to assist Malawi in its reduction of road accidents and crime. It will serve a population of about 80 thousand Malawian people from Traditional Authorities Kwataine, Makwangwala, and Champiti. The Nsipe Police Post is worth K188 million.   The donation occurred at a handover ceremony, where Chinese Ambassador to Malawi Liu Hongyang and Malawi Vice President Saulos Chilima were in attendance. In addition to the Nsipe Police Post, the Chinese government also donated furniture, five motorbikes, and a refrigerator to assist the new facility.
justification: Project is a social development initiative focused on public safety and infrastructure
evidence: Construction and donation of police post, furniture, motorbikes, and refrigerator for public safety purposes

title: China sponsors 50 Malawian students for ICT training in November 2021
description: On November 15, 2021, Huawei provided a week-long training at the 2021 Industrial Digital Transformation Conference in Lilongwe. The Chinese Government provided funding for 50 Malawian students to attend the training. The training series provided information on communication technology and it was completed on November 22, 2021. This training was part of the "Seeds for the Future" program, which began in Malawi in 2016. The monetary value of this educational funding is unknown.
combined_text:

title: Chinese Government provides security equipment to Malawi police force in April 2021
description: On April 29, 2021, the Chinese Government donated security equipment to the Malawi police force. The equipment included 300 tents, bullet proof vests, handcuffs, gas masks, shields, helmets, shock baton sticks and binoculars. The donation has a monetary value of MK200 million ($250,000 USD).   A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Lilongwe, the capital of Malawi. Malawi’s Minister of Homeland Security, Richard Chimwendo Banda, and China’s Ambassador to Malawi, Liu Hongyang, attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

The equipment included 300 tents, bullet proof vests, handcuffs, gas masks, shields, helmets, shock baton sticks and binoculars. The donation has a monetary value of MK200 million ($250,000 USD).   A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Lilongwe, the capital of Malawi. Malawi’s Minister of Homeland Security, Richard Chimwendo Banda, and China’s Ambassador to Malawi, Liu Hongyang, attended the ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of security equipment to police force, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact

title: China donates K24 million to the Shaping Our Future Foundation in December 2021 (Linked to Project ID#96949)
description: On December 3, 2021, the Chinese Government donated K24 million to the First Lady's Shaping Our Future Foundation in Malawi. The donation occurred at a handover ceremony which was held at the Presidential Palace of Malawi. Ambassador Liu Hongyang, President Ma's wife Monica Chakwila, and Vice Minister of Health Chrissy Kanyasho attended the ceremony and delivered speeches.   The donation will be used to fund education in Malawi and ensure that 120 girls stay in school. During the ceremony, the Chinese Government also donated medical supplies (Project ID#96949) amounting to K40 million.

title: BNM makes RMB 6.55 billion drawdown under currency swap agreement with PBOC in 2021 (Linked to Project ID#96202)
description: On February 8, 2009, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) — Malaysia’s central bank — and the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) signed an RMB 80 billion (MYR 40 billion) bilateral currency swap agreement to facilitate trade and improve foreign currency liquidity in Malaysia. On February 8, 2012, BNM and the PBOC renewed their bilateral currency swap agreement and increased the maximum drawing rights from RMB 80 billion (MYR 40 billion) to RMB 180 billion (MYR 90 billion). BNM and the PBOC renewed their bilateral currency swap agreement — with maximum drawing rights of RMB 180 billion (MYR 90 billion) — again on April 17, 2015, August 20, 2018, and April 17, 2020. BNM made two (gross) drawdowns under the currency swap agreement in 2020 and 2021: an RMB 7,169,923,934 (MYR 4,294,000,000) drawdown in 2020 and an RMB 6,558,437,637 (MYR 4,416,000,000) drawdown in 2021. The interest rate that applied to these borrowings is unknown. However, it is known that the maturity of each borrowing was approximately 1 year (12 months). It is also known that the amount outstanding under the PBOC swap line was RMB 7,169,923,934 (MYR 4,294,000,000) as of December 31, 2020 and RMB 6,558,437,637 (MYR 4,416,000,000) as of December 31, 2021.The 2020 drawdown is captured via Project ID#96202 and the 2021 drawdown is captured here.
staff_comments: 1. A bilateral currency swap (BCS) agreement — also known as a central bank liquidity swap agreement — is an agreement between the central banks of two countries to exchange cash flows in different currencies at predetermined rates over a specified period of time. Central banks participate in these agreements to facilitate bilateral trade settlements using their national currencies (rather than relying upon on a third-party currency such as the U.S. dollar), manage demands from their local banks, and provide liquidity support to financial markets. The party that draws down on the swap line becomes the borrower and the other party becomes lender. During the term of the swap, the party that draws down on the swap line makes either fixed or floating interest payments on the principal amount. If both parties draw down on the swap line, then both parties exchange fixed or floating interest payments on the principal amounts.  The 5-step process of drawing upon a currency swap line with the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) can described from the perspective of an importer in a given country (‘Country X’) seeking to settle trade with a Chinese firm in RMB. Step 1: The central bank of Country X and the PBOC activate their currency swap in advance, at which point each party deposits a specific amount of its currency in an account controlled by the other party (i.e. the central bank of Country X deposits local currency in an account controlled by the PBOC, and the PBOC deposits an equivalent amount in RMB in an account controlled by the central bank of Country X). Step 2: A firm in Country X that imports goods from China applies for an RMB-denominated loan from a domestic bank. Step 3: The domestic bank in Country X that receives the loan application then applies to its central bank for an RMB-denominated loan. After a review process, the central bank of Country X notifies the domestic bank applicant that its loan application was approved. The central bank of Country X subsequently requests that the PBOC transfer RMB funds from the central bank of Country X’s swap account within the PBOC to the loan applicant’s account with a corresponding bank in China. Step 4:  The domestic bank in Country X directs the corresponding bank in China to transfer RMB funds into a Chinese exporter’s account, and the corresponding bank in China provides RMB funds to the Chinese exporter. Step 5: The importer in Country X repays the RMB-denominated loan at its maturity date. The domestic bank notifies the central bank of Country X of the repayment, and transfers RMB into the central bank’s account within the PBOC through the corresponding bank in China. For the central bank of Country X, the RMB deposit is an asset that should be recorded on its balance sheet as an official reserve asset denominated in RMB. The contra entry of this asset is the liability in the local currency of Country X that represents China’s claims in the central bank of Country X. This should be also recorded on the balance sheet of the central bank of Country X. At the time of the exchange of currencies, it should be recorded as an increase in assets and an increase in liabilities of the monetary authorities in the balance of payments. The reason why the PBOC uses this mechanism to provide renminbi liquidity to other central bank is to increase the speed, convenience, and volume of transactions between the two countries. More detailed information about currency swaps with the PBOC can be found at https://www.imf.org/-/media/Files/Publications/WP/2021/English/wpiea2021210-print-pdf.ashx and https://thechinaguys.com/the-rise-of-the-renminbi-the-reality-of-bilateral-swap-agreements/ and https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/bop/2017/pdf/17-25a.pdf. 2. AidData treats drawdowns under BCS agreements with the PBOC as collateralized loans because, in a BCS arrangement, the currency of the borrower is held as collateral while the lender receives interest on the amount drawn down by the borrower until repayment is made. 3. Most central banks publish their end-of-year outstanding PBOC swap debt, but only a few report detailed transaction-level data on drawdowns during the year. Therefore, if no information on drawings is available, AidData assumes that total drawdowns during the reporting period equal the amount outstanding at the end of the reporting period (and vice versa). Since the (de jure) maturities of PBOC swap drawdowns are 12 months or less, this creates a lower bound estimate for actual drawdowns under the PBOC swap line. 4. PBOC swap debt is frequently rolled over. In central bank reports where one can only observe the year-end outstanding amount, no distinction between rollovers and drawdowns is possible. In these cases, one can derive (new) drawdowns as the difference between the current and last year’s outstanding swap debt stock. This measure essentially captures net lending (drawdowns) through the PBOC swap line.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
BNM makes RMB 6.55 billion drawdown under currency swap agreement with PBOC in 2021 (Linked to Project ID#96202)

# Description
On February 8, 2009, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) — Malaysia’s central bank — and the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) signed an RMB 80 billion (MYR 40 billion) bilateral currency swap agreement to facilitate trade and improve foreign currency liquidity in Malaysia. On February 8, 2012, BNM and the PBOC renewed their bilateral currency swap agreement and increased the maximum drawing rights from RMB 80 billion (MYR 40 billion) to RMB 180 billion (MYR 90 billion). BNM and the PBOC renewed their bilateral currency swap agreement — with maximum drawing rights of RMB 180 billion (MYR 90 billion) — again on April 17, 2015, August 20, 2018, and April 17, 2020. BNM made two (gross) drawdowns under the currency swap agreement in 2020 and 2021: an RMB 7,169,923,934 (MYR 4,294,000,000) drawdown in 2020 and an RMB 6,558,437,637 (MYR 4,416,000,000) drawdown in 2021. The interest rate that applied to these borrowings is unknown. However, it is known that the maturity of each borrowing was approximately 1 year (12 months). It is also known that the amount outstanding under the PBOC swap line was RMB 7,169,923,934 (MYR 4,294,000,000) as of December 31, 2020 and RMB 6,558,437,637 (MYR 4,416,000,000) as of December 31, 2021.The 2020 drawdown is captured via Project ID#96202 and the 2021 drawdown is captured here.
justification: Project involves currency swap agreements between central banks, which is a financial service with no direct environmental impact
evidence: Bilateral currency swap agreement between Bank Negara Malaysia and People's Bank of China, focused on trade facilitation and foreign currency liquidity
